div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular service fortnightly from HAMBURG, weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from Alexandria for Rotterdam and Hamburg. Goods fowarded at through-ates from all Germ Railway Stations on direct Bills of Ladings to Alexandria, Cairo, Syria, etc. Special facilites foor conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria, via Rotterdam and Hamburf to German manufacturing towns.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Cassa d Sconto e di Risparmio effects all Banking operations, such as Discount, Payments, Loans on Title, Deed, and Goods ; Letters of Credit issued. Drafts and telegraphic transfers on principal towns of Egypt and abroad. Custody of Titles Deeds, Purchase and sale of Debenture or other valuables ; Current accounts opened. The "Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio receives money in deposits at following rates: 2½ % for sight, 3½ % for 6 months, 4½ % for 1 year and over. div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: The weather yesterday was somewhat changeable Mild, though dull, in the early part of the day, i became cold and boisterous towards the close. Moderate S.W. gales sprang up, the wind travelling at the rate of 90 kilometres, an hour. To-day improved conditions prevail. The barometer is rising and fine weather may be expected.

div.head: ISLAM AND ENGLAND
div.p: The British Government has charge of the political welfare, and therefore to some extent of the social and spiritual welfare, of a larger number of Moslems than are the subjects of any other Government, and Mr. Morley, whose ability and administrative capacity have found their due scope at the India Office, undoubtedly realises as fully as anyone outside that office what is implied in ' that British re- sponsibility. His strong faith in representative institutions will cause him to welcome the new Moslem association, which certainly starts with a disposition to support the British Admi- nistration, regarded by Indian Mnalems as both efficient and just. The difficulty which may beset the Indian Government, says the "Morning Poet," is that as the Moslem League is to some extent a counterpart of the so-called Indian National Congress, in which the Hindu element is preponderant, there can be no question of the Government's favouring either one or the other organisation. But this is so well understood in India that there is not much likelihood of its being the cause of any dissatisfaction among the Moslems.

The British Government, as it seems to us, might do worse than take the initiative in the promotion of scientific education for the benefit of the Moslems of the Empire and all other Moslems, There is a wide field in the languages, literature, and history of the countries of Islam, all of which are in as close relation with Great Britain as with any other European State. It ought to be practicable so to develop in the University of London or in one or other of its colleges the field of study thus described that that university or that col- lege should attract students from India, from Egypt, and from Persia, and should be able to provide highly-trained Moslem professors and teachers not only to colleges like Aligarh but to other Indian institutions of like purpose, to the Gordon College at Khartoum, and pos- sibly also to Cairo, where Moslem students congregate mainly at present for religious instruction rather than in the pursuit of knowledges. If London is not thought by the leaders of Moslem sentiment in India to be the best centre for such an institution there ought to be little difficulty in finding it a home in India, where the Universities have hitherto attracted rather the Hindu than the Moslem element of the population. The spirit which inspired Lessing's dramatic poem "Nathan the Wise" would certainly appeal to many of the leaders of Moslem thought in India, who have the breadth of view that comes of a knowledge of the world and of a liberal culture

The revival of Islam is a phenomeon which has for many years past attracted the atten- tion of those whose occupations compel them to take an interest either in Asia or in Africa. It is to some extent the reaction against the pressure that has been exercised by Europe upon the world of Islam. Perhaps the movement in Egypt, at one time called nationalist, which led to the disturbances of 1882 and to the British occupation, was one of its first manifestations. There followed the Benousai movement in the back- lands of Algeria, perhaps not unconnected with the spread of Islam in the interior of Africa, which as regards the regions of the Central and Upper Niger and of the Great lakes is of very recent date. When last autumn Mr. Chirol delivered to the Central Asian Society his most interesting address on "The Pan-lslamic Movement" there were several well-known Indian Moslems present, I and two of them made speeches likely to be remembered by those who beard them. Mr. Chirol thought that the present Sultan of Turkey, by the stress which he has laid upon his position as Khalif, had contributed to the revival of Moslem feeling all the world over, and that his aim had been political. Upon this Mr. Ameer Aly declared that the Indian Moslems do not regard the Sultan as a rival with the British Government for their allegiance, and Major Syed Hassan described the revival of Islam as part of a reaction visible in all the backward countries of the world against injustice and obscurantism. This reaction was not to be feared in India, because the Indian Government is just, and free from obscurantism. Mr. Ameer Aly referred to the Austrian occupation of Bosnia and Hersegovina as one of the cases by which Modlems feels ag- grieved. He admitted that the Austrians had made roads and railways, but, he added, "in their wake have followed drinking and im- morality." It is evident that the Moslem revival deaerves to be followed with a sympathetic intelligence if its nature and possible couse- quences are to be appreciated.

div.head: White Slave League.
div.p: The White Slave League has decide to open a branch at Cairo

div.head: Tourist Steamer.
div.p: The S.S Arabic with 600 tourists on board, is expected here shortly from New York.

div.head: Army Manoevures.
div.p: The annual manoevres of the Army of Occupation are fixed to begin on February 26 on the Abbassieh polygon.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: The weekly report on the bubonic plague is of the most gratifying nature. No new cases are reported, and only two persons remain under treatment.

div.head: Egyptian Ivory.
div.p: Egyptian ivory to the amount of 18 tons had arrived in London last week for the quarterly sales, which were help on the 29th inst.

div.head: Appointments.
div.p: Messrs. E.) Shakerley and Wilfred Sharp have been appointed assistant engineers in the Sudan irrigation Service, at L.E. 35 per month. Mr. C. Crawley, director of works (second class) has been appointed director of works (first class) at an annual salary of L.E. 800.

div.head: A Theban Tomb.
div.p: Professor Maspero, Mr. Percy E. Newberry, and Mr. Theodore M. Davis have collaborated in the production of a work on the tomb of Ionua and Touiyou. It is to be illustrated by Mr. Howard Carter, and will be published shortly.

div.head: Nile Navigation.
div.p: The Irrigation Serive has decided to contruct a sadd across the Damiette branch of the Nile at Faraskur near Damiette. Consequently, navigation on the Damietta branch will be interruped at Faraskur from about the 15th March to 15 August.

div.head: Dorwning Accident.
div.p: Early this morning, a light in the outer harbour capsized oweing to the suddenly veering round, and two men and a boy who were on it were thrown into the sea. One man managed to save himself, but the other two drowned. Search is being made for thier bodies.

div.head: Old Alexandria.
div.p: Canon A. Ward gave a very interesting lecture on "Ancient Alexandria" last night at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute. Unfortunately the inclement weather prevented a large audience, but those who bravely faced the elements were amply rewarded by the most entertaing hour.

div.head: Murder at Minieh.
div.p: Our Minieh Correspondent repors that a murder was commited there of Tuesday night in a little frequented street, the victim being a certain Ahmed Hassanein, who was shot fatally. A soldier who happened in the neighbourhood arrested three men, but himself recieved a charge in the hand.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.
div.p: The annual general meeting of members of the British Chanmber of Commerce of Egypt will be help on Thursday, 14th February, at 4 p.m. in Messrs. Carver Bros.' officers rue de l'Ancienne Bourse, Alexandria, to recieve the committee's report and accounts for the year 1906 and to elect four members to the committee for 1907.

div.head: The Oasis of Jupiter Ammon.
div.p: There has been some trouble at Siwa owing to a quarrel between the inhabitants of the oasis and a number of Bedouins of the Anami family of the Waled Aly tribe, who camp habitually at Bir Garauli in the Aguba district. A party of these men were on their annual expedition to Siwa to get dates, when the inhabitants, fearing they were on a land-grabbing expedition, attacked them. Peace has, howeverm been made on condition that they should hie themselves homewards as soon as they have got their dates.

div.head: Egyptian Lady's Terribler Adventure
div.p: Our London Correspondent writes under date of Friday last : The young wife of an Egyptian stockbroker, Mrs. Halli Kemeid, was terribly injured at Ipswich yesterday by a bullock. Attracted, it is believed, by a red dress the lady was wearing, the beast rushed at her and tossed her bodily into the air. She fell upon the tranway lines in the middle of the road, with blood flowing from her head and ears, and was quite unconscious when picked up, remaining in the state late last evening. The husband of the unfortunate lady is at present in Egypt.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: The Turkish troops who are occupying Sollum, on the Egyptian-Tripolitan frontier, are behaving very badly to the Egyntian Bedouions in the neighboorhnod of the border. Our informent. who has just returned from the western frontier, states that there are now about a thousand Ottoman troops there. They are well armed and are still continuing to build forts. They are under the command of Aly Efiendi Ghanéen. As is the custom with the soldiers of the Sultan their pay is always in arrear, and so they have to subsist often by making foraging raids on the Bedouins. Recent- ly there was a regular fight between them and the Bedouins, and relations are now very strain ed owing to their continally committing depredations at the expense of the Egyptian Bedouins, who detest the Turks and their con- slant requisitions and robberies.

The Turks have now been in occupation of Solium for over two years although it has al- ways been considered Egyptian territory. In 1904 the Egyptian Government protested against their occupation of that place. The frontier line is very vague, as the firman of 1841 failed to specify it. The relations be- tween the Turks and the Egyptian Coastguard Administration are quite friendly. The nearest Egyptian Coastguard post to the Tripolitan frontier is at Sidi Bsrani, forty kilometres to the west of Marsa Matrouh.

div.head: KEHDIVIAL DECORATIONS
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has conferred the 3rd class of the Order of the Osmsnieh on Hussein Mchsrrem Pasha, 1st aide-de-camp to his Highness ; Watson Pasha ; aide-de-camp ; Ahmed Chawky Bey, chief of the translations bureau of the Khédivial Cabinet ; and Mr. John Right, inspector to the Khassa Khédi- viale.

The King has granted the undermentioned officers authority to accept and wear decorations which have been conferred upon them by the Khedive in recognition of valuable services rendered by them to his Highness :— Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, Third Clsss.—Major (local Lieutenant-Colonel) Ernest Berdoe Wilkinson, Lincolnshire Regi- ment. Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh, Third Class.— Major Godfrey Estcourt Mat- thews, Royal Marines. Imperial Ottoman Under of the Osmanieh. Fourth Class.— Captain Ernest Douglas Young, Devonshire Regiment ; Captian Ernest Somerville Jackson, Welsh Regiment. Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjdieh, Fourth Class.- Quartermaster (Honorary Lieutenant) William Henry Dale, Royal Engineers.

div.head: THE INCREASE OF CRIME
div.p: "AI Watan" says :—' The omdebs too often imagine that they are made of a different clay and nobler dust than their fellow-villagers. Result—an attitude of contempt and disdain. The people put up with it, fearing the couse qoences of opposition, denunciations, false charges, perjured witnesses, etc, etc... But matters do not end wilh this. The families of the victims avenge their wrongs and crime answers crime. In short it is the omdehs who have unchained the forces of criminality and have themselves a been guilty of criminality towards the State and their country."

"Ah uno disce omnes " is hardly a safe motto to follow in discussing criminality and its causes, and our contemporary appears to us to show a certain bias against a class of men whose functions are in the last degree difficult, whose lives are often endangered by criminals, and whose reputation is constantly attacked by every species of blackmailer.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: The Liverpool University Council have elected Mr. Percy E Newberry to the Brunner chair of Egyptology and Mr. John Garstang to the John Rankin chair of the Methods and Practice of Archaeology.

Profesor Newberry, after studying at King's College School and King's College, London, has for the past sixteen years been continuously engaged in archaeological research in Egypt or at home. He has also written "The Life of Bekhmara," "Scarabs: An Introduction to the Study of Egyptian Seals and Signet Rings," and, in association with Professor Garstang,"A Short History of Ancient Egypt."

Professor Garstung, on leaving Blackburn Grammar School, became a mathematicial scholar of Jesus College, Oxford, graduating in 1899. After conducting various excavations at Roman sites in England, he drawn into work in Egyptian first in connecting with the Egyptian Research Account and then as assistant to Professor Finders Petrie on the staff of the Egyptian Exploration Fund. In 1902 he was appointed Honorary Reader in Egyptian Archeaology by Universtiy College, Liverpool.
The terms of appointment are such as to leave both professors free for a certain portion of each year to continue their work of exploration and research wherever opportunity may serve.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S Keffer Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 30th inst. and is due at Alexandria on Sunday.
The Moss liner Seti sailed this morning for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 5,888 bales cotton.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR.
div.p: A Havas telegram from St. Peterburg states that the official version of the demonstration against the Russian Consolate at Alexandria haa been published there. It shows that Boutros Pasha Ghali immediately expressed his regrets to M; Smyrnoff.
The police authorities are enquiring into charges of aggression made against 10 Europeans, who assaulted the polie in the course of the recent anti-Russian disturbances.

Mr. Michael Zanganakins, the Cretan who was injured by the mob in the outrage at the Russian Consolate on Sunday week, has quite recovered from the rough treatment he received. He was mauled about the head and sto- mach because he tried to preserve the Imperial coat-of arms from insult. He has been thanked by the Russian consular authorities for his conduct.

div.head: A NEW COMPANY.
div.p: Messrs. Arditi and Co., who are one of the oldest and most respected firms of stock and share broken at Cairo and Alexandria, are turning their business into a company under the name of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt. The new company will take over the business of Messrs. Arditi and Co., and its objects are both financial and commercial, and will embrace all the usual functions connected with dealings in stocks, shares, cotton, and other produce.

The capital the company is £125,000, of which £120,000 will be in Ordinary shares of £1 each and £5,000 in Deferred shares of £1 each. The capital can be raised to £500,000 on the decision of the board.

div.head: P.W.D SALARIES.
div.p: The following increases of salary have been authorzed by Ministerial decree :—M. Fierz from L.E. 800 to L E. 900 ; Mr. H. G Fin- laison from 800 to 900 ; M. Reboul from 700 to 800 ; Mr. P. R. Boxwell from 600 to 700 ; Mr E Lambton and M L M. Cooper from 480 to 600 ; Abmed Eff. Rached from 414 to 528 ; Ahmed Eff. Rauf from 396 to 528 ; Mr. Fits- Patrick from 276 to 366.
Fifty employés have had their salaries, ranging between L.E 60 and L B 240, raised to L E 66 and L E 300 a year. Increases have also been granted to fifteen engineers, to date from January 1.

div.head: VACCINATION AT ALAEXANDRIA
div.p: The Alexandria Municipality has supplied vaccine to no less than 30,000 persons since the beginning of December. It is estimated that before that date only about a quarter of the European population of the city had been vaccinated, and large numbers still are too indifferent or too ignorant to understand the extreme necessity of the operation.

Since the 1st January there have been 47 cases of small pox among Europeans, while the huge native popolation has only had 23 cases, and the Turks, Syrians, Armenians, and the local subjects (notified collectively as "Otto- mans") have had only 15 cases.

The number of persons vaccinated during the Kourban-Beyram holidays has shown a remarkable falling-off, and it is sincerely to be hoped that in the interests of the public health of Alexandria this decrease will not be main- tained. From the 1st December the returns for every five days of cases of small pox in Alexandria have been as follows : December 2, 5, 2, 6, 10, 9 ; January, 17, 12, 6, 22, 16, The Attarin quarter of the city is responsible for an enormous preponderance, about 60 per cent., in the number of the cases, and this quarter is especially inhabited by Europeans of the poorer classes.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MATERNITY HOME.
div.p: The ball given at the New Khedivial Hotel last night on behalf of the work of the Alexandria lying institution "La Maternité," was very largely attended. The ladies of the committee, Mrs. Kingham, Mrs. Choremi. Mrs. Rotbacker, Mrs. Chataway, Mrs. Charles Bacos, Mrs. Em. Zervodachi, Mrs. Morrison, and Mrs Debbane, deserve to be congratulated on the success of the ball, which ought to materially assist the financial resources of one of the most deserving charities in Alexandria sup- ported by voluntary funds. The Home has been in existence for some years past doing really good work. Started at the outset in a very small and humble way, and after going through many and varied vicissitudes, almost at times appearing doomed to fail in its good work, at last it ranks as one of the foremost of our most valued charities. The Home not only recieved many patients gratis, but also is able to offer nursing and treatment to those in a position to be able to pay for their mainte- nance, and therefore there is a certain amount of accommodation for some few 1st and 2nd class patients as well. Madame Antony, the matron of this excellent institutions, is a person who deserves the highest praise and commen- dation for her entiring efforts to ensure the entire success which has to-day been achieved in this work. Her devotion to her work and interest therein conld not readily be surpassed. Last year she conceived the idea of trying to established a small créche (residential) in con- nnection with the Home. For this pur- pose a wooden room was constructed in the very small ground surrounding the Home and in it today there are no less then 13 children, all of whom were born in the Home itself. The whole work seems to be steadily increasing, and at this moment funds are sorely needed, as the committee are faced with the fact that they will have to find other suitable quarters, as the present house will not be available very much longer, and the ques- tion arises as to whether it will not be advisable to build a permanent Maternity Hospital with the residential crêche combined. An appeal is made for any left-off clothes or in fact anything that might be considered useful and acceptable, for either these poor women or their children'

div.head:
BEYRAM AT ASSOUAN.
ANNUAL BALL AT CATARACT HOTEL.
div.p: The management of this popular hotel was taxed to the utmost to deal with the number of visitors duting Beyram. The usual amuse- ment committee was formed and arranged a programme of entertainments which left not a dull moment during the festival. A two days' tennis tournament and other out door amusements beguiled the hours of sunlight, whilst the evenings were taken up with bridge, impromptu dances, and drawing room games. The principal event of the week was the annual fancy dress ball, which was held in the magnificent Moorish dining hall of the hotel on Friday evening.

For days before all hands were busy secretly planning and executing their surprises for the occassion. The event surpassed the efforts of all previous years, the fancy costumes were worn at dinner, and the arrival of each new character was greeted with ever increasing interest end delight. There were some 300 present when dancing began. Prizes were given for the best lady's and gentleman's comstumes, which were decided by ballot. The lady's prise fell to Mrs. Courteuld as Jill, of bucket of water fame. Her costume was complex simple munditiis and effective. Mr. Lance Tackeray, as the "Big Game Hunter," secured the gentleman's prize. This product of a fertile imagination exhibited much ingenuity. Amongst those present in costumes were : Mlle de Komar and Miss Wanklyo, who were ran- nere up for the first price ; Mrs. Pembroke, as a Dresden shepherdes ; Mrs. Lambert, poudré; Mrs. Garner, house-maid ; Mrs. Porteous Scott, modiste ; Miss Ewart, Grecian costume ; Miss K. Ewart, as Matches ; Miss Warner, as Great Grand Mother ; Miss Ethsl Wanklyn, as a gipsy ; Mrs. Atmstrong, poudré ; Miss Armstrong, a Circassian lady ; Miss Cooper, Oriental costume ; Miss Dunlop, as Rainbow ; Miss William, as Doll Varden; Mrs. Stevens, poudré; Mrs. Brand, poudré ; Miss Bigsby, Lady Jeffrey, Miss Lombe, as a French peasant ; Miss Lemouins, "No tramps"; Miss Pilkinton, as tha Duchess of Devonshire.

Sir Robert Dashwood, Bart., appeared as an Egyptian Pasha in gorgeous attire ; Baron von Stumm, as Phaorah, Mr. Watt, as Mephisto, and Mr. Lockhart, as Rouge-et Noir, were highly commended. Mr. L. M. Ewart, as a lady, almost defied detection, so deftly did he manage his skirts. Mr. Brand appeared as Tarantella; Mr. Willan, as a Venetian Blind; Mr. Pembroke, as Jack Point. Mr. U quhart was a fiery captain with the inevitable cigar ; Mr. Stuart Mackenzie Low represented Chinese Labour ; Mr. Akinga Brothers, a M. F. H. in pink coat and brown gaiters, sustained his reputational the local sportsman; Dr Keat- inge looked the part of an Arab horse dealer ; Mr. Man's, as a ballet dancer, was one of the creations of the evening ; Mr. Carey was an Arab sheikh. Two well-known Austrian painters, Messrs. Kriter and Delitz, made up a delightful gollywog, causing much amusement. The nigger minstrel troupe, Messrs. Warner and Mandslay (the latter with his dog Scamp), Mr. Otway and Mr. Boyes, as the blushing Belle, were literally a howling success Col. Arm- strong came as the Last of the Dandies. A large hat with Mr. White underneath was seen crawl- ing about as the Mad Hatter.

Amongst those noticed at dinner were : Sir Charles Wyndban, Sir W. and Lady Ewart, Sir Alfred Cooper and Miss Cooper, Messrs. A. L Webb, H. Aspinal, Algernon Perkins, A. Haines, Bishop and Mrs. Morley, the Bishop of Madras. Mr. and Mrs. Macdonald, Mr. Maooorqnedale, Critty Bey, Dr. Garner, Mr. and Mrs. Talbot Kelly, Mr. F. Ogilvie, Dr. Cafferata. Dr. Call, etc.

A good deal of the success of the evening was due to the excellent management, under the direction of Mr. R Steiger. In the small hours of the morning many of the visitors sat down to a most enjoyable supper which was brought to a happy conclusion with music and song.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "Tinkle tinkle Machera. How I wonder what you are!" was our sorrowful reflection on Toss- day night at thn Zizinia. The piece is one of Verdi's earliest efforts, in which the music is al- most aa thin as the plot: we say almost, for were it quite as thin it would cease be music at all Sig. Emilio Marchi has, we are glad to observe, nearly thrown off his cold ; we still hold to it that he is as much a baritone as a tenor, for his lower notes are freer and less tired than his upper compass, which is indeed not insusceptible of greater clarity and distinction. His play throughout is polished and admirable. Again we have pleasure in commending Signa. Chotkowski Ladislows, whose voice is as sym pathetic as her appearance. The orchestra was good, but has few opportunities in a piece that contains hardly any orchestration ; and some- how the who'e performance seemed to start better than it ended. May be one was regret-ting that, as the company apparently wishes to give us antiquities, it does not boldly revert to Mozart and Gluck.

div.head: CAIRO'S NEW HOTEL.
div.p: The latest addition to the famous Bucher- Durrer hotels, the Semiramis, is to open its decors to the pubic next week; and though much remains to be done before its completion, there it no doubt that it will be found on February 7 to be one of the most magnificently equipped and furnished hotels not only in Egypt but in Europe.

Facing the river, in close proximity to the Kasr el Nil Bridge, it enjoys the advantage of being in the very best and most fashionable quarter of Cairo without any of the discomforts by being in the town. Its frontage on the river bank it of magnificent apperance and noble proportions, and the western wing overlooking the palace of the Khedivah Mother enjoys a view up the river and across to the pyramids of Sakksrab which cannot be equalled. A handsome wide verandah makea an ideal lounge overlooking the river, and the facade of the hotel is ornamented in the ornate Baroce style, lofty pillars of red marble, with innumerable balconies and loggias, all adding to its elaborate effect.

The handsome end well-proportioned vesti- bule is lined with marble and adorned with immense mirrors, marble columns supporting the richly decorated ceiling. A very elegant drawing room decorated in rococco Louis XVI. style in cream and gold with moral panels of Gobelin tapestry leads from it on the one side, and on the other are the two fine restaurants, the one deoorated is green with much green marble and the second in pink with carved mahogany fitments. For the present moment these restaurants will take the place of the dining-hall, which latter building will not be completed for several weeks ; and until the big ball room ies finished, the evening entertainments will take place in a most charming room of somewhat lesser proportions which lies at the back of the vestibule and which is a delightful example of the Empire period. Handaome stained glass tempers the glare of the sky lights of this attractive room, end the musicians' gallery also adds greatly to its appearanoe.

Enough bedrooms will be completed and furnished by the opening day to accomidate some 250 guests ; and all these rooms are equally beautiful in their arrangements and furnishing. Private suites can be obtained to suit all requirements, and many of these have private entrances and other conviences. There are most capacious cupboards in many of the passages and rooms ; and some seventy bathrooms are distributed among the rooms to be ready by February 7. Double doors keep away all chance of draught and noise and special filments to the outside blinds greatly facilitate the raising and 1owering of these cumbersome necessities. As for the furnishing of the pretty bedrooms with their bangings of pale blue, green, pink, or yellow, these are all carried out in the best of taste and harmony. Messrs. Keller & Co., of Zurich, are responsible for much of the beautiful Empire furniture, while the comfortable-looking brass bedsteads are all of English manufacture.

One of the greatest improvments in Egyptian hotel schemes is the delighful garden which is to make the root of the Semiramis ose of its cheif attractions. Here has been erected a café- restaurant and pavilions, and here private dinners and tea parties will be served, the lifts bringing it within the reach of all. At present this hotel is the highest in Cairo ; and the view from its roof over the length and breadth of the town and to the marvellous country beyond is an education to those who have never witnessed the panorama.

It is a long drop from the roof to the kitchens and other offices of the hotel, but a visit to these necessary, it unornamental, quar- ters is necessary to realize the work that is being done there. The kitchens are immense apartments containing stoves of all sorts and sites, ovens for pastry, silver grille, and various others too technical for a mere cursory glimpse. There are wonderful engines and machine shops, too, on this floor, boilers for providing the steam besting apparatus which is found in every room, huge engines for the supply of electricity, and many other unwieldy looking machines, while in the adjoining garage may be found electric motor cars of the latest pattern. Further visits to the wine cellars and larders, also to the laundry, the linen room, and those in which is stored the plate and chins, are apt to fill this mind with envy and the head with fatigue ; hot are essential in forming an idea of what this wonderful Bucher-Durrer Company is capable of doing.

The above description cannot be taken as a complete account of the new Hotel Semiramis; abd no mention das yet been made of the billiard room and bar, which is as fine and complete in its arrangements as the other apartments. At some near future date the hotel will be surrounted by a luxurious garden, but at the present one can only draw upon one's imagination to guest the effect it then makes.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Colonel R.C.C. Cox, commanding, and officers 2nd Batt. Ruyal lnniskilling Fosiliers, the band will perform the following programme of music at the Helouan races on Friday:
March — Die Garder der Mark — Kruger

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Norfolk left Arundel Castle last Thursday for London, on their way to Egypt, and will be absent from England for several weeks.
The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe will leave England shortly for a Mediterranean crusie, and will in all probability pay a visit to Egypt.

The Duchess of Buckingham and chandos and Earl Egerton, who have been residing for several weeks at Tatton Park, the family seat in Cheshire, left England on Friday on their way to Egypt, and will be away until the End of April.
Lord Cromer is leaving Cairo on the 3rd proxo. for Upper Egpy, going as far as Assouan. His lordship will be absent from the capital three weeks.
Lord Royston arrived in Cairo yesterday.
The Earl of Yarmouth, who is now at Cimiez intends coming on to Egypt in a week.
Lord Hastings, who is to marry Miss Madge Nevill on the 19th proxo., is coming to Egypt for his honeymoon.

Ladt D'Arcy Osborne is coming to Egypt. Some years ago Lady D' Arcy tried camping out in the desert in Egypt as a "cure," and dervied much benefit from it, so much so that she has carried out the same programme each year. This year, after a short stay in Cairo, she proposes visiting Palestine.
Lady Csmoys is one of those who are on their way to Egypt.
The Hon. Henry Cubitt, Lord Lieutenant of Surrey, and Mrs. Cubitt are leaving for Egypt in a day or two, and will be absent from England till after Easter.
Sire Ernest Cassel and Sir Benjamin Baker, who arrived at Port Said from Marseilles by the Mooltan, are at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo.

Among the many visitors staying at Mena House Hotel we notice H.R.H. Prince Benya of Siam, Sir John Ardagh, Susan Countess of Malmesbury, Sir Eyre Coote, Lady Coote, Mustapha Patha Fehtmy, Fabricius Pasha, Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn and party, Mr. Ronald Hamilton, Dr. Hess Bey, Mr. Bacos and family, Mr. E. Chappell, Miss Chappell.
The Hon. Claude Yorke leaves Cairo to-day for Assouan.

Sir Michael Foster, K.C.B., F.R.S., D.C.L., S.Sc., L.L.D., whose death is announced to-day, was born in 1836 and started his career as a surgeon at Huntingdon. He soon was recognised as one of the first physiologists of the day and held in sucession the posts of teacher and professor of practical physiology at University College, London, of Physiology at Cambridge. From 1881 to 1903 he was secretary to the Royal Society and represented London University in Parliament up to last year.
A marriage has been arragned and will fake plave early in february between Katherine Mary, widow of the alte Dr. Noel Unsworth, and Mr. Maurice Moberly, Governor of Touvah Prison.

Another engagement which has lately become public property is that of Miss Sheldon Amos and Major Elgood. Miss Amos is no stranger to us, her parents, the late Judge and Mrs. Amos, having passed many years in the country, and her brother, Judge Sheldon Amos, being also very well-known here. Miss Amos has made for herself a very welcome and enviable position. She is a fully qualified lady doctor, and in that capacity holds a good appointment in connection with the girls Government schools. She has also giver her most valuable services in the cause of Lady Cromer's dispensaries, and much of their success is due to her indefatigable zeal. Major Elgood, who was for many years inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, was recently appointed director of the police school, Cairo.
The many friends of Mr. Rooff, formerly general manager of the Khedivial steamship line, will be pleased to hear that he has arrived at Alexandria and has put up at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.
Mrs. Willmore, wife of Judge Willmore and her sister, Miss Caillard, are also staying at the same hotel.
"Pierre Loti" has sent a letter to "Al Lewa," expressing thanks for the compliments paid to him on Sunday afternoon at the Contintal hotel, at the Ottoman fets.
The King of Italy has conferred the Cross of the Crown of Italy on M. Camillo Ceato, proprietor of the Abbas Theatre, Cario. M. beato is also decorated with the "Palmes academiques francaises."

div.head:
RUSSIAN FAMINE
APPEAL TO ANGLO-SAXON RACE.

div.p: M. Shishkoff, a member of the National Assembly and of the relief Association, has arriced in England after a visit to the famine stricken districts in South-Eastern Russia. In a letter to the "Times" he depicts pathetically the awful visitation, and passionately appeals to the benevolence of the Anglo-Saxon race. Hundreds of thousands of people are on the brink of starvation, and are eating bread made of acrons, rye, and straw. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN TERRORISM.
PRISON GOVERNOR SHOT DEAD.

div.p: The governor of the prison to which political prisoners are committed here was shot dead in the main street of the city this morning. He was a makred man owing to his alleged maltreatment of political prisoners. His assailant escaped. (Reuter)

The Duma election returns officially issued here indicate that the COnservatives and Moderates have secured a sweeping majority. The revolutionaries declare that the returns have been "doctored" in order to show the liberal defeats, but they admit the increase in the conservative votes, espiecally among the peasantry. (Reuter)
The Chamber and the Senate have passed the Budget.
The Chamber has passed the bill according to which it is no longer necessary to make a previous declaration for the holding of public meetings. (Havas)
M. Biancheri, President of the Chamber, has resigned. (Havas)

The Emperor, in the rescript thanking his people for their birthday congratulations, land the brillant way the mass of the electorate demonstrated to the while world it patriotism and loyaly and appreciation of the Empire's great civilizing tasks. (Reuter)
An expedition has succeeded in promptly crushing the Kediri rising. (Reuter)
Eighty-five men have been entombed owing to a colliery explosion at Faretteville (Virginia) (Reuter)
The funeral of the victims of the mine explosion was of a imposing character. (H.)

div.head:
POPE AND FRANCE.
DOOR OPEN TO CONCILIATION.

div.p: In their declaration, approved by the Pope, the French Bishops agree to submit to the Law of 1907 provided that the hierarchy is recognised an that contracts be concluded between the communal authorities and the priests guaranteering the latter the permanent use of churches.

The press considers that the door is open to conciliation. However, M. Briand, speaking in the Chmaber of Deputies yesterday evening described the Bishops' terms as unacceptable ; he appealed to the majority to assist the Government in its difficult task. (Reuter)
The "Globe" announces that the resignation of Sir J. Swettenham has been accepted. (R.)
Sir Micheal Foster, K.C.B., is dead (R.)

div.head: SALT & SODA.
div.p: At the general meeting held on the 27th December last, the shareholders of this company authorized the creation of 50,000 new shares, of which 30,000 were to be issued immediately and the remaining 20,000 later on. This increase of the company's capital was decided on in view of the arrangment made by the directors with regard to the redemption of the 1,000 Founders' shares appearing on the debit side for a sum of 1,000.
The balance-sheet of the company on the 31st August was as follows :

row.cell: Cash in Hand and in Bank … ...
Cash in Hand of debentures trustees.

div.p: Including the balance brought forward from the preceding year, the profits of the company amount then to L.B. 69,935. The enormous increase of the profits in 1906, compared with those 0f 1904-1905, which were L.E. 12,540 only, appears, at the outset, to be highly satisfactory, but a serious examination of the balance sheet figures of there two years shows, firstly, that the real profits of the last twelve months are only L.E 28,885, is, an increase of L.E 16,345 only on the preceeding year ; secondly, that reserve acconnts, which amounted to L.E 90,908 in the balance-sheet of 1904-1905, are, in the last one, a decrease of L.E. 41,100 on the preceding year. This increase should, therefore, be practically consider- ed as a reduction of the LE 69,785 in profit. Thus we arrive at the real amount of profit, which is, as before mentioned, L.E. 28,885.

We must recognize, however, that the situation of the company is now much better than it was in 1904-1905, many reductions in the expenses having been made since then. A dividend of 9 1/2 per cent, was paid on the ordinary shares,
The deferred shares having received a total dividend of... 2,544
The balance of the year's profit, i.e . ... 34,533
will be employed by the board of directors in the redemption of the founders' shares, and also in paying off several items of the assets

But, from another point of view, we should not overlook the fact that the company will have to remunerate, in future, a total capital of £600,000, represented by 500,000 shares of £1 and £100,000 of debentures, and that so large a capital will require net profits of £30,000 per annum, at least.

div.head: Sudan Government
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. this contract should be explained and signed by the Labour yers in presence of an official or other reliable witness.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Col. Nevil Macready, C.B., lately A.Q.M.G., Cape Colony district, has been appointed A.A.G at Head Quarters. This officer served on the Staff in Egpyt from 1884-1888.

Lieutenant R.L.H. Conlan, 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Egypt, at home, has been placed on duty with the draft which the Depot Squadrom of the Inniskillling Dragoons, Ballincollin, has prepared to join the regiment at Cairo, and will embark with it at Southampton about the 13th prox.
It is announced that the Army Council has approved of the expenditure of 6,000 for increased accomidation for the troops in Egypt.

On the 5th prox., Sir George J.S. Warrender, Barl, the new Commodore of the east Indies Squardon, will hoist his broad pennant on the second class crusier Hyacinth at Portsmonth, on which date she will be brought up to her full complement of 450 of all ranks.

After the Lagos marceavres, the first class battleship Lonfon, Captain J.C.A. Wilkinson, will return home to pay off, and will not rejoin the Mediterranean Fleet. The London, most likely, will be commissioned with a nucleus crew for service in the Reserve.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITIOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair place to al, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—With yoar kind permission I should like to offer a few remarks on "Engineer's" letter in your issue of the 28th inst. If that gentleman could make it convenient to visit the works in progress, I feel sure he would be greatly interested ; and, 1 venture to think, not unwilling to add another ought to the figures he suggests as representing the quan- tity of imported material actually in position and on the ground awaiting placement. The buildings composing the college consist of three distinct blocks of truly noble proportions, be- sides several subsidiary buildings not yet commenced, which, I understand, are intended for the accommodation of the teaching staff. The convocation hall, as I suppose I may designate it, is almost 200 feet long, with a span of 50 feet, and the girders—not joists— which support the floor above are very massive, and consequently of considerable weight each. The questions of quantity or weight, however, is to my mind of only secondary importance, and the less the quantity actually is, the more I think it is to be regretted that material of British origin was not stipulated for, consider- ing the object the structure and patriotic feeling which called it into existence. —Yours truly,

div.head: BULGARIA AND EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—I read your yesterday's article on Bulgaria's political disabilities with interest, beacuse the status of that Principality is no less problematical than that of this so xalled Vilayet of the Ottoman Empire. Indeed there is a striking parallel between them. Ferdinand Effendi is de jure just as much a vassal of the Porte as is Abbas Pasha as far as household politics go ; one is backed by Russia and the other by Great Britain,internationally speaking. This form of veiled protectorate is galling enough to Turkey, but it seems that this does not satisfy -your European diplomatists, who are essaying an experiment on premises which legally, do not exist. I refer to the request of Bulgaria, one Vilayet, for an exequatur for its Diplomatie Agent in Egypt, another Vilayet Surely the Porte has a politioal conscience just as much as any other national entity Or is the Sultan a foreign potentate all to gather ? Granted that political con-siderations have decentralized the former jurisdiction of the' Ottoman Porte to the vassal States of Bulgaria and Egypt ; this is in the gift of the Sovereign. The gronnd work on which this arrangement rests is the same as before, and that groundwork is international law, according to which Egypt and Bulgaria are "intrgral parts of the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte," Our international jurists, who an opportunists, now propose to change this ground work, so as to appoint a Bulgarian Diplomatic Envoy to the Court of Abdin. Soon we shall hear of their applying to the powers that be for the exequatur of an Ottoman Diplomatic Agent at Cairo and Sofia.—Yours, etc,

div.head: SQUASH RAQUET TOURNAMENT.
div.p: A very interesting squash racquet handicap tournament has been in progress the last fortnight, 27 players having entered. There have been some excellent matches. The semi final was played yesterday, the competitors being Capt. Timmins (handicap—7) and Mr. Greville (handicap—5). The rallies throughout were very good. Capt. Timmins, being in better practice, eventually won.
Second game. - Mr. Greville had matters his own way, winning 15 to 2.
Third game.—Went to Capt. Timmins by 15 to 9.
In the finals Capt Timmins—7 will play Mr. Crake - 2.

div.head: "FIT FOR NOTHING."
div.p: "I worked at the looms in a woollen mill with hundreds of girls, and i lnown that none of us took proper care when aches and pains gave warning of approaching troubles." These works fo Miss Ellen Lamb, of 565. Killings-worth-road, Undercliffe, Bradford, point a lesson to all her sex, for by disregarding oft-recurring ailments, and neglecting lapses of health, such as backaches, headahces, chills, fits of languor and faintness- by which Nature signals a coming breakdown- women pay a heavy penalty.

"In my case," said Miss Lamb, "I gradually became so irritable, work went wrong and seemed to jar on my nerves ; all day I felt wretched, and by the time work was finished quite "done up." Then I had strange lapses of memory, while dreadful neuralgic pains would shoot across my shoulders and through my head. Dizziness, with a sense of sickenss, would come voer me, and I would tremble violently. Fainting fits often attacked me in the street, and I had to suddenly clutch at the railings or pause in doorways. I had heavy headaches, and

became unbearable. Sometimes a creeping sensation would run along my nerves or muscles, then sharp throbbing pains would be felt as though my head was splitting open. I suffered a good deal from indegestion, but this time my digestive powers were so weark that food was rejected after almost every meal. I had long ago lost all colour, and had fallen away in weight terribly.

I lost all vitality: even my speech became confused. Food tasted horrible: my favourite cup of tea seemed naucesous. Sleep at night was almost impossible, and I was not fit for the lightest work. Throughout y illness I have the help of kind doctos, but none of their medicine seemed to have any lasting effect. Friends recommended one thing and another. I tried almost everything, but still the pains and weakness increased. I felt at last that no cure existed for my case, and lost all hope.
"Then a friend who assured me that she has suffered intensely, told me that if I would only take Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, I would, like her, soon be well and strong again.

"I took her advice and begain these pills. At first I did not notice much difference, but a great surprise was in store. Soon I actually felt hungry and ready to eat, food seemed appetising, and gave me no pain or sickness. I was delighted to find health coming bak like that, and I continued the pills. Food nourished me, and restored my lost flesh. My colour slowly returned and my spirits became cheerful. After a few boxes I lost all backaches and headaches. My sight became clearer and my circulation improved. I no longer became dizzy or faint, and
Life was something like Life Again
to me. Now I am in the best of health, and always feel well, thanks to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills."

Dr. Williams' Pink Pills have cured thousands of weak ailing, wretched men and women by making Good, Rich, Red Blood and feeding the tired nerves. In this way they have cured Anaemia, 1 digestion, eczema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St. Vitus' Dance, Neuraliga, Paralysis; also the special troubles of girls and women. 2s 9d. for one box, or 13s. 9d. for six, post feww, from the British Depot; 36, Holborn-visduct, London; sold also by dealers, but mind your ask for Dr. Willians, for substitutes never cure.

div.head: The Egyptian Cotton Mills, Limited.
div.p: The Shareholders of the above Company are invited to attend an informal meeting to be held on 5 February 1907 at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Cairo at 6 o'clock evening for the purpose of recieving and deliberating on important proposals concerning the interests of the Company.
Shareholders desiring to attend the Meeting must produce at the Meeting either Bearer Warrants or a certificate showing the deposit of their shares in a Bank.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should foward all t estimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagments since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 er mensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted inot the Government service.

div.head: ALEXADNRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: Owners of bicycles, tricycles, motor cycles, and hand carts, including barrel organs, are informed that numbered plaques will be applied to them free by the Municipality. For those who hold a plaque for 1906 a diatinctive mark for 1907 will be added. Applications must be made to the Service des Recettes before February 28, 1907, Sundays and holidays excepted, by the owners, so as to have the plaques or distinctive marks put on to their vehicles. After the above date, if any of the above mentioned vehicles are found circulating without a plaque or distinctive mark their owners will be liable to prosecution.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: L'ensemble du marché est admirablement tenu, en dépit de que'ques reculs partiels. Ou traite surtout les nouxelles émissions, l'Agri- cole, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, les Batatas, l'Urbaine, le Comptoir et la Port Said Salt.

L'Arditi (Bourse and Banking Co) s'avance tiès demandée è 1 7/16 l'actioo et £ 25 la part de fondateur; les Risx cotent 1 17/3, la Hooker 1 1/4, la Lunghis 11/2; la Livioo est t èa ferme è 1 7/16 l'action et £ 20 la part de fonda- teur ; quant è l' United, elle est pins faib'e è 1 3/16 l' action et 8 7/8 la part de fondateur.
Les Agrioole ont fait fureur durant toute la matinée. Elles cloutent a 9 13/16 7/8. On entrevoit généralement une forts accentuation de 1a hausse dans le oourant de février.

En hausse également les Privilégiées Tram ways è 20t, les Jouissance! Baux du Caire a 298, lea Cotton Milia à 6/9, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier è 340, les Noogoviuh Hotels k 23 1/16, la Delta Land k 4 1/2 U Nile Laud k 19, les Bitatea k 2 5/8, la part de fondateur Comptoir k 91, la Banque d'Orient è 134, et l'action Allotment k 3 9/16.

Par contre, la National Bank reoule è 28 1/16, la Ramleh k 6 5/16, la Delta Light k 11 1/2, la Dividende Tramways k 368. acheteurs, la Filature k 5/4, la Salt & Soda 23/6, la Barque d'Athènes k 135 1/2, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail k 35, l'action Comptoir a 7 7/8 l'ancienne et 7 7/16 la nouvelle, la Building a 6 1/4, l'Union Fonciere a 6 1/8, et la part de fondateur Allotment a 135.
La liquidation de fiu janvier est virtuelle ment terminée. Une grande partie des positions ont été reportées a fiu féxrier. D'autres ont été allégées dans le courant mémo de janvier.

MM. Arditi and Co, ageuts de change des plus anciennement et avantageusement connus d'Alexandrie et du Caire, transforment leur éta- blissement en Socété anonyme, sous le nom ds Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt, Limited.

La nouvelle societé prendra la suite des affaires de la maison Arditi and Cn. et aura ponr ot jet principal les opérations de courtage en fonda publics et marchandises aux Bourses dn Caire st d'Alexandrie, ainsi que les arbi- trage* entre ces deux places et les Bourses étraagiree.

Le capital initial est de £ 125,010 do t £ 120,000 en notions ordinaires de £ 1 e' £ 5,000 en deferred de 1 £ également ; ce ca- pital pourra dans la suite être porté a £ 500,000 sur simple décision du Conseil d'admioistra tion.
Nous apprenons que 1a nouvelle émission de 100,000 actions Orliuaires Khedivial Mail aura probablement lien dans la seconde quin zaine du mois de Février, et son succès est déja assuré.
Le prix de l'émission des nouxelles actions est de £ 1-7 6 par action, et elles seront an porteur, franco de droit de timbre.
Les détenteurs des notions anciennes auront le droit de souscrire dans la proportion de 71 actions nouvelles pour 100 auciennces soit pri-vilégiées, soit ordinaires.
La somme de 7/6 par aotiuo sera payable a la souscription et le solde a la répartition.
Les actions nouvelles participerout aux bé néfioes de l'exeroioe en cours à partir de la date de la répartition

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres eit reité k 4 7/8 malgré les grands besoins de la liquidation de fiu de mois. Au Stook Exchange le Consolidé anglais s'eit maintenu k 87 et l'Unifiée à 102 1/2. La National Bauk a avancé de 1/8 k VH 1/4 et TAjrioole de 1/8 également k 9 3/4. La Difra est demsurée inchangée a 17 1/2, de même que la Delta Light a 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier s'est tenu immo- bile a 777. La Barque d'Athènes a gagné 1 frano a 138.

Ici, la sésnoe de ce matin a été oe qu'elle devait etre, c'est a-dire calme, aveo affaires restreintes et tendance indécise, déterminée par les rffits d'une I quidatiou de fiu de mois laborieuse, aggravée par le resserrement mo- né'aire. Il y a toutefois lieu de noter que les oours ont piésen'é une ré-i tance de bon augure; plusieurs titres ont même bénéficié d'une avance.

Dans le compartiment des Barques, la Na- tional est remon'ée a 28 l/16 1/8 L'Agricole, assez mouxemeutée a avancé à 9 3/4, sur di- verses rumeurs do it la confirmation est su- jette a caution. La Caisa di Soonto a encore regagné 5 francs à 385,a près avoir atteint 290. La part de fondateur du Comptoir Financ er a faibli k £ 97 et la part de la Socié é Géné rale Egyptienne a 103 francs.
Le Crédit Foncier s'est inscuit a 776 777 et sa part a 940 950. La Daira a progressé a 17 5/8.

Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux ont été ramenées a 16 par des realisations et des ventes motivees par la liquidation. Leur part, qui a é é t'ol'j it de transactions ountinues, a, pour le même motif, décliné ju qu'a 3"5 pour remonter, surdes achats, k 317 3 8. L'E pargne Immobilière a été cotée 3 5/8, sa part s'est alourdie k 3 0, ce qui la met a un prix très tentant. L'Express Nile et resté a 5 1/2 et sa part k 3 5.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont progressé k 291. Les Automobiles se sont tassé u a 5 5/16-3/8 ; leur part a fléchi è 10 1/2.
Dana le groupe dee valeurs hôtelières, les Nnngoxich ont avancé à 23. Les Egyptian ont faibli è 12 3/8 et les Upper Egypt k 4 3/4. Les National se to t raffermis a 3 7/8-15/16.

Parmi les petitea valeurs, la Delta Land s'est raffermie a 4 3/8. La part de fondateur Estâtes a avancé a 21 7/8 22. Les Abdy se sont con solidés a 1 5/16 et les New Egyptian a 31 sh 9. Les Salt aud Soda ont encore progressé a 24 sh. 6 sur la persis'ance d'une rumeur suivant laquelle les négociations pour une fusion aveo la Port Said Salt Association se-raient a la veiled etre repreises. La Port Said a avance a 16 sh. 3.

Ainsi que nous l'avions annoncé dans no re Circulaire d'axaut-hier, une réunion plén ère des membres du conseil d'administration de Londres et d'Bgypto de la Delta Land Co. a été tenue hier an Caire, sous la préddence de sir Aucklaud Colvin.

Nous tenons de soiree autorisée que toutes, les divergences de vues exi-tint entre les deux Boards ont é é rég'éss dans oette asssmb'ée. Il a été déridé que 'a gestion des afftires de 1a Société sera oor fiée a l'avenir an Board local, qui sera renforcé de denx membres nouveaux, oe qni portera lenr nombre total a quatre oontre trois a Londres.

On rapporte, d'antre rart, que la disjonction proposée des liens entre la Delta Light Railways e' la Delta L»ud a été abandonnée, les tri- b maux le Loo 1res ayant -et-ieé de la sa action ner k moins q le 1a dernière So iélé n'ait modifié sa r'éo mir ation.

Pour ce qui est de la question des égouts dn Caire, il e-t actuellement avéé que le go i verre- meut a rnj ité le projst de fixer leur déverse ment dans la dircc ion de Tonrab on d'Hélnnan, et Ton s'attend a ce qu'un oommun'qué du ministère des travaux publics calme les ap-préhensions que les rumeors répandues a ce propos, dans la vue de de erminer une depreciation des propriete dans ces parages, ont causees au public.

Ce matin, a 10 heures, est veono devant la ohambre commerciale du Tribunal mixte do Caire 1a mise en cansede M Paul Oziol, en sa qualité d'ex cen-enr de la Société des Sncreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte dans le procès en dom- mages inté êts intenté par M. Ardoine Fklonioo d'Alexandrie aux adminutratenra et censeurs de ce De Société de chef du préjudice cansé au demandeur par 'es bilans publiée qui l'avaient mené a acheter des actions a des prix élevés nullement justifiés. L'affaire a été renvoyée ponr être plaidée a qustre semaines.

Nos lecteurs trouverout, joint en supplement a notre Circulaire de ce jour, le compte rendu détaillé de l'assemblee generale extraordinaire des actionaries de la Societe d'Enterprises Immobilières et de Travaux qui a été tenue hier an siège social au Caire.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
